case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the respondent company

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 729-732 of 1965 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 729-732 of 1965. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals are by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 3, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 196 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 3, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 196 of 1960.

facts.text: The respondent is a public limited company carrying on business of life and general insurance.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a public limited companypany, carried on in the relevant years of account business of insurance- life and general.

facts.text: In calendar years 1944 to 1948 relating to assessment years 1945-46 to 1950-51, the Company suffered loss in the life insurance section and made profit in the general insurance section.

anchor.surface_text: In each of the calendar years 1944 to 1948 relating to the assessment years 1945-46 to 1950-51, the Company suffered loss in the life insurance section, and made profit in the general insurance section.

facts.text: Till assessment year 1950-51, loss in life insurance was allowed to be carried forward and set off against profits from general insurance under s. 24(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Till the assessment year 1950-51 the loss suffered in the life insurance section was allowed by the Revenue authorities to be carried forward and set off under s. 24  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, against profits from the general insurance section in the subsequent year.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, Income-tax Officer held life insurance and general insurance businesses are distinct and separate, loss from life cannot be set off against general profits under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment for the assessment year 1951-52 the Income- tax Officer held that the life insurance business and the general insurance business carried on by the Company were ,distinct and separate and the loss carried forward from the previous year in respect of life insurance business companyld number be set off under s. 24  2  against the profit of the general insurance business.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal confirmed the Income-tax Officer's view.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal companyfirmed the view of the Incometax Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Madras High Court under s.66(1): Whether unabsorbed losses in life insurance from earlier years available to set off against general insurance profits for 1951-52 to 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Madras under s. 66  1  of the Income-tax Act Whether the unabsorbed losses incurred by the assessee in the earlier years in its life insurance business are available to be set off against its profits from general insurance business for the assessment years 1951-52 to 1954-55?

facts.text: Madras High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appeals preferred by Commissioner of Income-tax with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, these appeals have been preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Tribunal stated business of life insurance possesses peculiar characteristics different from other insurance businesses.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal states The business of life insurance possesses peculiar characteristics which do number exist in respect of other insurance businesses.

facts.text: Life insurance policies are not contracts of indemnity but forms of investments; other insurance are contracts of indemnity.

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, the life insurance policies are number companytracts of indemnity they are forms of investments. Other classes of insurance business are companytracts of in- demnity.

facts.text: Life insurance contract continues until death; general insurance is generally annual.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, the companytract in the general insurance is generally annual while in the case of life business the risk companytinues until death.

facts.text: Life business controlled by different principles from general insurance.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, life business is companytrolled by principles essentially variant from those which companytrol the general insurance business.

facts.text: Assessable profits of life business computed separately from general business.

anchor.surface_text: lastly, assessable profits of life business shall be companyputed separately from those of the general business, the companysequence of which would be that the carry forward of loss of life business cannot- be had against the profit of general business.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds life insurance and general insurance constitute the same business within s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: in our view therefore the High Court was right in holding that the life insurance business and the general insurance business companystitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24  2  of the Act.

facts.text: Company entitled to carry both businesses under Memorandum of Association.

anchor.surface_text: the Company was entitled to carry on the life insurance business and the general insurance business under its Memorandum of Association,

facts.text: Businesses attended by same Branch Managers and Agents without distinction.

anchor.surface_text: and the businesses were attended to by the Branch Managers and the Agents without any distinction, there was one companymon administrative organization

facts.text: Common administrative organization and common expenses for both businesses.

anchor.surface_text: there was one companymon administrative organization and the expenses incurred in companynection with the business both for administration and for heads of expenditure such as salary of the staff, postage, staff welfare fund and general charges, were companymon.

facts.text: Appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Loss carry forward allowed under s.24(2) for assessment years 1951-52 to 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 729-732 of 1965. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 3, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 196 of 1960. M. Hazarnavis, Gopal Singh and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in all the appeals . Swaminathan and M. S. Narasimhan, for the respondent  in all the appeals . The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Profits of life insurance computed separately under Rule 1 of Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: By r. it is provided that in the case of any person who carries on, or at any time in the preceding year carried on, life insurance business, the profits and gains of such person from that business shall be companyputed separately from his income, profits or gains from any other business.

facts.text: Counsel for Commissioner contended life and general are separate businesses based on computation methods.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner companytended that life insurance business and general insurance business were separate businesses and he relied in support of that companytention primarily upon the method of companyputation of taxable income of the life insurance business and of the general insurance business.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejects test of whether one business can be closed without affecting the other as decisive.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with companynsel for the Commissioner that the test whether one of the businesses can be closed without affecting the companyduct of the other business, is a decisive test in determining whether the two companystitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24  2 .

issues.text: Whether the unabsorbed losses incurred by the assessee in the earlier years in its life insurance business are available to be set off against its profits from general insurance business for the assessment years 1951-52 to 1954-55?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the unabsorbed losses incurred by the assessee in the earlier years in its life insurance business are available to be set off against its profits from general insurance business for the assessment years 1951-52 to 1954-55?

issues.text: whether the business of life insurance and the business of general insurance could be regarded as the same business

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the business of life insurance and the business of general insurance could be regarded as the same business assumes importance in this case, since the right to carry forward the loss suffered in the life insurance business and to set it off against the profit of the company in the general insurance business of the subsequent year is clearly in issue.

arguments.claim: Life insurance business and general insurance business are distinct and separate; loss from life insurance cannot be set off under s.24(2) against general insurance profits

arguments.claim: High Court correctly held life and general insurance constitute same business under s.24(2)

anchor.surface_text: in our view therefore the High Court was right in holding that the life insurance business and the general insurance business constitute the same business

holdings.text: the life insurance business and the general insurance business constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: in our view therefore the High Court was right in holding that the life insurance business and the general insurance business constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court applied 'inter-connection, interlacing, inter-dependence, unity' test from Scales v. George Thompson, finding common management, organization, administration, fund, and place of business despite separate computation methods.

holdings.text: distinct methods of computation of taxable income do not mean that life insurance and general insurance cannot be the same business within s. 24(2)

anchor.surface_text: But because there are distinct methods of computation of taxable income of the insurance business, and the general provisions of the Income-tax Act relating to computation of profits and gains of a business in s. 10 and the related sections are inapplicable, it does not follow that the two businesses cannot be the same business within the meaning of s. 24(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special computation rules in Schedule override general provisions but do not define business sameness, which turns on organization and management, not tax computation methods.

holdings.text: Whether businesses are the same or different depends not on computation methods but on nature, organization, management, capital source, bookkeeping, and related circumstances

anchor.surface_text: Whether two or more lines of businesses may be regarded as the same business or different businesses depends not upon the special, methods prescribed by the Income-tax Act for computation of the taxable income, but upon the nature of the businesses, the nature of their organisation, management, the source of the capital fund utilised, methods of book-keeping and a host of other related circumstances which stamp the businesses as same or distinct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sameness determined by operational and structural unity, rejecting reliance on tax computation distinctions.

holdings.text: test whether one business can be closed without affecting the other is not a decisive test for whether they constitute the same business under s. 24(2)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with counsel for the Commissioner that the test whether one of the businesses can be closed without affecting the conduct of the other business, is a decisive test in determining whether the two constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Closure independence provides indication but not conclusive; interdependence strengthens but does not mandate sameness.

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in holding different computation methods make life and general insurance not the same business under s. 24(2)

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunals judgment proceeds not upon any special circumstances governing the distinctive organization, management, account, methods of book-keeping or the peculiarities of the two businesses, but primarily upon the provisions of the Income-tax Act which provide different methods of computation of the taxable income of the life insurance business and- of the general insurance business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal improperly focused on computation rules instead of organizational facts.

holdings.text: A fairly adequate test for same business is interconnection, interlacing, interdependence, unity embracing the businesses (from Scales v. George Thompson)

anchor.surface_text: A fairly adequate test for determining whether the two constitute the same business is furnished by what Rowlatt, J. said in Scales v. George Thompson Co. Ltd Was there any inter-connection, any interlacing, any inter-dependence, any unity at all embracing those two businesses ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts and applies English precedent test to facts showing common elements.

holdings.text: inter-connection, interlacing, inter-dependence and unity exist here via common management, business organisation, administration, fund and place of business

anchor.surface_text: That inter-connection, interlacing, inter-dependence and unity are furnished in this case by the existence of common management, common business Organisation, common administration, common fund and a common place of business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of common structure satisfy Scales test.

holdings.text: appeals fail and are dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent on upholding High Court on merits.

anchor.surface_text: But because there are distinct methods of computation of taxable income of the insurance business, and the general provisions of the Income-tax Act relating to computation of profits and gains of a business in s. 10 and the related sections are inapplicable, it does not follow that the two businesses cannot be the same business within the meaning of s. 24(2).
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: he general insurance business. Both in respect of the life insurance business and general insurance business, there are, as already mentioned, special

edges.explanation: holding addresses the issue by specifying factors beyond computation methods for determining if businesses are the same

anchor.surface_text: Whether two or more lines of businesses may be regarded as the same business or different businesses depends not upon the special, methods prescribed by the Income-tax Act for computation of the taxable income, but upon the nature of the businesses, the nature of their organisation, management, the source of the capital fund utilised, methods of book-keeping and a host of other related circumstances which stamp the businesses as same or distinct.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: holding addresses the issue by rejecting the closing test as decisive for sameness under s. 24(2)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with counsel for the Commissioner that the test whether one of the businesses can be closed without affecting the conduct of the other business, is a decisive test in determining whether the two constitute the same business within the meaning of s. 24 2 .
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunals judgment proceeds not upon any special circumstances governing the distinctive organization, management, account, methods of book-keeping or the peculiarities of the two businesses, but primarily upon the provisions of the Income-tax Act which provide different methods of computation of the taxable income of the life insurance business and- of the general insurance business.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: A fairly adequate test for determining whether the two constitute the same business is furnished by what Rowlatt, J. said in Scales v. George Thompson Co. Ltd Was there any inter-connection, any interlacing, any inter-dependence, any unity at all embracing those two businesses ?
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.
